name: Erebor
description: Erebor, the Lonely Mountain, is the ancient dwarven stronghold and kingdom, famed for its vast treasure hoard and pivotal role in Middle-earth's history.

content.title: Overview
content.body: Erebor, known as the Lonely Mountain, is a massive, solitary peak situated to the east of Mirkwood. It was originally home to a prosperous kingdom of dwarves, renowned for their mining and smithing skills, and filled with riches amassed over centuries. Its deep halls and intricate tunnel systems boast unparalleled craftsmanship and wealth. Erebor also commands key strategic importance due to its position between the wild lands and civilized regions to the west.

content.title: Appearance
content.body: The Lonely Mountain rises prominently above the surrounding landscape, standing isolated amidst rolling hills and wilderness. Its cavernous interior is composed of vast underground halls adorned with intricate stonework, statues, and subterranean cities. The mountain's chambers contain immense treasure hoards—gold, gems, and crafted artifacts—that dwarf the wealth of most realms. The silhouette of Erebor itself is iconic, projecting an imposing, crown-like profile against the sky.

content.title: History
content.body: Originally settled and ruled by dwarf kings, Erebor flourished for generations until the greed of its treasures attracted the dragon Smaug, who seized the mountain and its riches, forcing the dwarves into exile. The kingdom lay desolate for decades until Thorin Oakenshield and a company of dwarves embarked on a quest to reclaim their homeland. This reclamation culminated in the Battle of Five Armies, which marked a significant turning point in the region’s history and the reestablishment of the dwarven kingdom.

content.title: Story Significance
content.body: Erebor serves as the central objective for Thorin’s quest in 'The Hobbit,' symbolizing lost heritage, greed, and the reclaiming of one's rightful place. The mountain's treasure hoard and Smaug’s occupation are catalysts for the major events and conflicts driving the narrative. The restoration of Erebor epitomizes themes of courage, loss, and restoration. Post-conflict, the mountain becomes a key power base in Northern Middle-earth, influencing subsequent events in Tolkien’s legendarium.
